verses.text: Moses and the elders of Israel commanded the people, saying, 'Keep all the commands that I am giving you today.'
verses.comment: The command to keep all the laws emphasizes complete obedience to God's instruction, foreshadowing the call to keep the fullness of the faith (James 2:10).

verses.text: When you cross over the Jordan into the land the LORD your God is giving you, you must set up large stones and coat them with plaster.
verses.comment: The act of setting up stones signifies a visible, enduring testimony to God's covenant. The physical signs prefigure the later use of material means in God's ongoing relationship with His people.

verses.text: Write on them all the words of this law once you have crossed over, so that you may enter the land the LORD your God is giving you, a land flowing with milk and honey, as the LORD, the God of your fathers, has promised you.
verses.comment: Writing the law reminds us of the importance of preserving and honoring God's revelation, similar to the later inscribing of the New Covenant upon the heart (Jer. 31:33).

verses.text: And when you have crossed the Jordan, you are to set up these stones, just as I command you today, on Mount Ebal, and you are to coat them with plaster.
verses.comment: Mount Ebal becomes the place of covenant renewal. Physical locations often play a significant role in spiritual milestones, highlighting God’s interaction in history.

verses.text: Build there an altar to the LORD your God, an altar of stones. Do not use any iron tool on them.
verses.comment: The command against using iron tools reflects the holiness of worship, and the distinction between God’s work and human manipulation. The pure altar points toward later unblemished sacrifices (Lev. 1:3).

verses.text: Build the altar of the LORD your God with uncut stones and offer burnt offerings on it to the LORD your God.
verses.comment: Burnt offerings were made for atonement and dedication. The use of uncut stones again sets the worship of the true God apart, preparing the way for the true and final sacrifice (Heb. 10:10).

verses.text: Sacrifice fellowship offerings and eat there, rejoicing before the LORD your God.
verses.comment: Meals with offerings symbolize communion and thanksgiving with God, prefiguring later communal meals of worship in God's presence (1 Cor. 10:16-18).

verses.text: And you shall write very clearly all the words of this law on these stones you have set up.
verses.comment: A public display of the law makes God's will accessible, anticipating the new law to be inscribed on the heart by God's Spirit.

verses.text: Then Moses and the Levitical priests said to all Israel, 'Be silent and listen, Israel! Today you have become the people of the LORD your God.'
verses.comment: Becoming God's people through covenant reflects how God gathers a special people, fulfilled in the assembly of the faithful (Rom. 9:25-26).

verses.text: Obey the voice of the LORD your God and follow his commandments and decrees that I give you today.'
verses.comment: Listening and obedience are paired, preparing for Christ's own obedience to the Father's will (Phil. 2:8) and calling believers to follow.

verses.text: That day Moses commanded the people, 'When you have crossed the Jordan, these tribes will stand on Mount Gerizim to bless the people: Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Joseph, and Benjamin;
verses.comment: The tribes set to bless recall the importance of spoken blessing and the unique calling of each tribe, foreshadowing blessings pronounced in New Testament worship (Eph. 1:3).

verses.text: and these tribes will stand on Mount Ebal to pronounce the curse: Reuben, Gad, Asher, Zebulun, Dan, and Naphtali.
verses.comment: Blessing and curse were spoken from two mountains, emphasizing the seriousness of covenant faithfulness, a pattern recapitulated by Jesus in the Beatitudes (Matt. 5-7).

verses.text: The Levites shall declare to all the people of Israel in a loud voice:
verses.comment: The Levites' public proclamation prefigures later liturgical practices where designated leaders guide the people in worship.

verses.text: The Levites shall recite to all the people of Israel these curses:
verses.comment: Public recitation of blessings and curses reinforces communal responsibility for faithfulness, anticipating corporate confession in future assemblies (Neh. 8:1-8).

verses.text: 'Cursed is anyone who makes a carved or cast idol—an abomination to the LORD, the work of a craftsman's hands—and sets it up in secret.' And all the people shall say, 'Amen!'
verses.comment: Idolatry is especially condemned; secrecy suggests accountability even for hidden sins. The communal 'Amen' expresses whole-hearted acceptance, reflecting agreement in worship.

verses.text: 'Cursed is anyone who dishonors his father or mother.' And all the people shall say, 'Amen!'
verses.comment: Respect for parents is central in both covenants (Eph. 6:1-3), and the solemn curse warns against disregarding this. Family structure holds theological significance as a model for God’s household.

verses.text: 'Cursed is anyone who moves his neighbor's boundary marker.' And all the people shall say, 'Amen!'
verses.comment: Property rights protected here underscore justice and respect for others. There's a broader meaning about respecting the inheritance and rights established by God.

verses.text: 'Cursed is anyone who leads the blind astray on the road.' And all the people shall say, 'Amen!'
verses.comment: Compassion for the vulnerable is essential to God’s law. Spiritually, leading others astray has grave consequences (Matt. 18:6) and points to the importance of sound teaching.

verses.text: 'Cursed is anyone who perverts justice due to the resident alien, the fatherless, or the widow.' And all the people shall say, 'Amen!'
verses.comment: God’s concern for social justice is underlined, with a persistent biblical theme of caring for the marginalized (James 1:27).

verses.text: 'Cursed is anyone who lies with his father’s wife, for he has uncovered his father’s nakedness.' And all the people shall say, 'Amen!'
verses.comment: Sexual purity within the family is key to holiness. The law condemns actions that defile the body, anticipating New Testament calls for sanctity (1 Cor. 6:18).

verses.text: 'Cursed is anyone who lies with any animal.' And all the people shall say, 'Amen!'
verses.comment: Bestiality is condemned, reinforcing that the purpose of sexuality is holy and ordered by God. The communal response underscores universal moral law.

verses.text: 'Cursed is anyone who lies with his sister, the daughter of his father or his mother.' And all the people shall say, 'Amen!'
verses.comment: Incest is explicitly forbidden, again showing that God's law covers even the most secret personal actions and thoughts.

verses.text: 'Cursed is anyone who lies with his mother-in-law.' And all the people shall say, 'Amen!'
verses.comment: This affirms the sanctity of marriage and family structure, showing the interconnectedness of moral and social life. Repeated amen responses reflect participation of all in accepting God’s just standard.

verses.text: 'Cursed is anyone who attacks his neighbor in secret.' And all the people shall say, 'Amen!'
verses.comment: Secret violence is condemned, reiterating that one’s relationship with neighbor is a crucial part of covenant faithfulness (1 John 3:15).

verses.text: 'Cursed is anyone who accepts a bribe to kill an innocent person.' And all the people shall say, 'Amen!'
verses.comment: Justice must not be perverted through bribery, especially at the cost of innocent life. This foreshadows the emphasis on righteousness and the sanctity of human life in the teachings of Jesus (Matt. 5:21).

verses.text: 'Cursed is anyone who does not uphold the words of this law by carrying them out.' And all the people shall say, 'Amen!'
verses.comment: This final curse warns that even failing to observe the whole law makes one liable. Paul quotes this to show the need for grace (Gal. 3:10-13), pointing ahead to Christ who fulfills the law perfectly for us.
